title: 114_hr4042
content: The Act may be cited as the "Pre-K for USA Act." It includes findings related to the Act. The United States ranks 25th in early learning enrollment, with studies showing that access to high-quality prekindergarten programs leads to academic success and cost savings. Prekindergarten attendance linked to lower drug problems, felonies, and arrests, higher GPAs, college attendance. 40% of districts lack pre-K, over half offer only part-day programs. Texas missed out on $118.48 million in Federal funding for pre-K expansion. Reports indicated that in 2011, the Texas legislature cut $5.4 billion in education funding, including $200 million in grants for expanding prekindergarten programs. In response, some local governments funded full-day prekindergarten programs, prompting a need for direct federal funding for prekindergarten programs in certain localities. SEC. 3. PREKINDERGARTEN DEVELOPMENT GRANTS. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will award competitive grants to increase capacity for high-quality prekindergarten programs. Grants will be awarded for up to 3 years and applications can be submitted by Governors, chief executive officers of States, local educational agencies, or other local government entities. To receive a grant under this Act, a government entity must submit an application to the Secretary of Education. States must consult with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care when developing their grant applications. Eligibility for a grant under this Act requires a matching requirement from the State, local educational agency, or other local entity. To receive a grant under this Act, a State or local government entity must provide non-Federal matching funds equal to at least 20% of the grant amount. This can be done through State funding, local funding, private contributions, or in-kind contributions. The Secretary may waive or reduce matching funds required for a grant application if extreme financial hardship is demonstrated. (e) Subgrants may be awarded to eligible local entities by a State, local educational agency, or other local government entity that received a grant under this subtitle to carry out grant activities. Subgrantees must comply with the requirements of this Act. Double-dipping prevention measures prohibit the Secretary from awarding a subgrant to a local educational agency or local government entity for a program in a fiscal year if the State has already provided funding for it. Authorization of Appropriations: $750,000,000 for fiscal year 2016 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2017 through 2025. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, an eligible local entity includes a local educational agency, an entity that carries out an early childhood education program, or a consortium of such entities. An eligible local entity for a high-quality prekindergarten program can be a local educational agency, an entity running an early childhood education program, or a consortium of such entities. A full-day program must be equivalent to a full school day and last at least 5 hours. The program must meet nationally recognized standards and serve children. The high-quality prekindergarten program must serve children aged 3 or 4, or those who have reached the legal age for State-funded prekindergarten. It also requires high staff qualifications, including teachers with a bachelor's degree. The high-quality prekindergarten program requires teachers to have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field, or demonstrate knowledge through a State-approved assessment. The high-quality prekindergarten program requires teachers to have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field, engage in ongoing professional development for at least 2 years, and be enrolled in a State-approved educator preparation program with ongoing training and support in early childhood education. The high-quality prekindergarten program requires teachers to have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field, engage in ongoing professional development for at least 2 years, and maintain a maximum class size of 20 children with a child to instructional staff ratio not exceeding 10 to 1, offering a full-day program with developmentally appropriate learning. The prekindergarten program provides developmentally appropriate learning environments, aligns with State standards, offers competitive salaries for instructional staff, conducts ongoing monitoring and evaluation for improvement, and provides comprehensive services for children including screenings for vision and dental. The prekindergarten program offers screenings for vision, dental, health, and development, along with family engagement opportunities and support services for parents. The prekindergarten program provides services such as parent education, family literacy, and nutrition services including nutritious meals and age-appropriate nutrition education for children and families. The prekindergarten program offers services for families, including parent education, family literacy, nutrition services, and physical activity programs aligned with evidence-based guidelines. The prekindergarten program offers high-quality professional development for staff, including in-class observation for teachers and teacher assistants. Additional support services are provided on-site for children with disabilities based on a needs analysis. The prekindergarten program provides professional development for staff through in-class observation and evidence-based coaching. It also ensures education and health standards are met. The terms "local educational agency" and "State" are defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" in the context of education refers to the Secretary of Education as defined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
